review.title: A Transition-Based Directed Acyclic Graph Parser for UCCA
review.abstract: We present the first parser for UCCA, a cross-linguistically applicable framework for semantic representation, which builds on extensive typological work and supports rapid annotation. UCCA poses a challenge for existing parsing techniques, as it exhibits reentrancy (resulting in DAG structures), discontinuous structures and non-terminal nodes corresponding to complex semantic units. To our knowledge, the conjunction of these formal properties is not supported by any existing parser. Our transition-based parser, which uses a novel transition set and features based on bidirectional LSTMs, has value not just for UCCA parsing: its ability to handle more general graph structures can inform the development of parsers for other semantic DAG structures, and in languages that frequently use discontinuous structures.
histories: 16 pages; Accepted as long paper at ACL2017
16 pages; Accepted as long paper at ACL2017

metadata.title: A Transition-Based Directed Acyclic Graph Parser for UCCA

sections.text: ar Xiv: 170 4.00 552v 2 [cs.C L] 4A pr2 017Cross-linguistically applicable framework for semantic representation that builds on extensive typological work and supports rapid annotation. UCCA poses a challenge to existing parsing techniques because it exhibits re-entry (leading to DAG structures), has discontinuous structures and non-terminal nodes that correspond to complex semantic units. To our knowledge, no existing parser supports linking these formal properties. Our transitional-based parser, which uses a novel transition set and functions based on bidirectional LSTMs, has value not only for UCCA parsing: its ability to handle more general graph structures can influence the development of parsers for other semantic DAG structures, in languages that frequently use discontinuous structures.

It has also proved useful for machine translation evaluation (Birch et al., 2016). UCCA differs from syntactic schemes in terms of content and formal structure. sections.heading: 5 Results
sections.text: Table 2 presents our most important experimental results, as well as the upper limits for the baseline parsers, reflecting the error resulting from the conversion. 10DAGParser and UPARSE are most directly comparable to TUPASparse, as they also use a perceptron classifier with sparse characteristics. TUPASparse performs significantly better than both where DAGParser does not predict remote edges in the out-of-domain environment. TurboParser performs worse in this comparison, despite slightly better results at the remote edges. The LSTM parser from Dyer et al. (2015) achieves the highest primary value among baseline parsers, with considerable marginality. With an upstream NN and the embedding of functions, TUPAMLP achieves higher values than TUPASparse, but is surpassed by the LSTM parser from Dyer et al. (2015).

sections.heading: 6 Related Work
sections.text: While previous work on the syntax-semantic interface has been used as the basis for semantic analysis by definition, the work focuses on the semantic role designation of verbal argumentation structures, the focus has lately shifted to the analysis of more complex representations that take into account a wider range of phenomena. [12] We have also experimented with a simpler version of TUPA without REMOTE transitions, which requires an increase of up to 2 marked F-score points to primary edges, at the expense of the inability to predict distant effects. [12] Semantic representation corresponds directly with the words and phrases of the text. (Evening and Rappoport, 2017).Grammar-based parsing. Linguistically expressive grammars such as HPSG (Pollard and Sag, 1994), CCG (Steedman, 2000) and TAG (Joshi and Schabes, 1997) provide a theory of syntax-semantic interface and have been used as the basis for analyses.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: We introduce TUPA, the first parser for UCCA. Analyzed in domain and extra-domain settings, we show that when combined with an NN classifier and a BiLSTM feature extractor, it accurately predicts UCCA graphs from text, significantly outperforming a variety of strong baselines. Despite the recent variety of semantic analyses, the effectiveness of different approaches to structurally and semantically different schemes is not well understood (Kuhlmann and Oepen, 2016). Our contribution to this literature is a general parser that explores multiple parents, discontinuous units and non-terminal nodes. Future work will evaluate TUPA in a multilingual environment and evaluate the linguistic applicability of UCCA. We will also apply the TUPA transition scheme to various objectives, including AMR and SDP, exploring the limitations of its universality. In addition, we will evaluate different conversion methods (UCCA et al, 2015), we believe that a different framework for different types of application is possible.

sections.text: This work was supported by the HUJI Cyber Security Research Center in collaboration with the Israel National Cyber Bureau in the Prime Minister's Office and the Intel Collaborative Research Institute for Computational Intelligence (ICRI-CI). The first author was supported by a scholarship from the Edmond and Lily Safra Center for Brain Sciences. We thank Wolfgang Maier, Nathan Schneider, Elior Sulem and the anonymous reviewers for their helpful comments.

sections.heading: A Feature Templates
sections.text: Figure 6 shows the feature templates used by TUPASparse. All feature templates define binary features. The other classifiers use the same elements listed in the feature templates, but all categorical features are replaced by vector embedding, and all count-based features are replaced by their numerical value. For some of the features, we used the term header, defined by the h х function (see Appendix D). Although headwords are not explicitly represented in the UCCA scheme, these features prove useful for encoding word-to-word relationships.

sections.heading: B Extended Presentation of UCCA
sections.text: This paper does not address two important constructions at the UCCA founding level: linkage, which represents discourse relationships, and implicit, which represents hidden entities. Table 3 shows the statistics of nodes and edges and implicit nodes in corpora.Linkage. Figure 7 shows a linkage relationship, which is omitted in Figure 1a. Linkage relationship is represented by the gray node. LA is linkage argument and LR is linkage relationship. The relationship represents the fact that the linkage "after" links the two parallel scenes, which are arguments of linkage. Linkage relationships are another source of multiple parents for a node, which we do not yet handle when distributing and evaluating. Implicit entities may contain UCCA diagrams without these coinciding in the text. Figure 8 shows the annexation for a tree is almost impossible to apply to another phrase similar to cotton.

sections.text: Table 4 lists the hyperparameter values that we have found for the different classifiers by tuning to the development set. Note that the decay of the learning rate is multiplicative and is applied in each epoch. Minibatch size is the number of transitions, but a minibatch may only contain whole sets.

sections.text: The conversion into a bilexical diagram requires the calculation of the algorithms used in G. We define a linear order by possible priority categories.

We are further motivated by the strength of transition-based methods in related tasks, including dependency graph parsing (Sagae and Tsujii, 2008; Ribeyre et al., 2014; Tokgöz and Eryiğit, 2015), constituency parsing (Sagae and Lavie, 2005; Zhang and Clark, 2009; Zhu et al.
, 2014; Tokgöz and Eryiğit, 2015), constituency parsing (Sagae and Lavie, 2005; Zhang and Clark, 2009; Zhu et al., 2013; Maier, 2015; Maier and Lichte, 2016), AMR parsing (Wang et al.
, with multi-word expressions (Schneider et al., 2014).

Transition-based parsers (Nivre, 2003) scan the text from start to end, and create the parse incrementally by applying a transition at each step to the parser’s state, defined using three data structures: a buffer B of tokens and nodes to be processed, a stack S of nodes currently being processed, and a graph G = (V,E, l) of constructed nodes and edges, where V is the set of nodes, E is the set of edges, and l : E → L is the label function, L being the set of possible labels.

In addition to the standard SHIFT and REDUCE operations, we follow previous work in transitionbased constituency parsing (Sagae and Lavie, 2005), adding the NODE transition for creating new non-terminal nodes.

To support the prediction of multiple parents, node and edge transitions leave the stack unchanged, as in other work on transition-based dependency graph parsing (Sagae and Tsujii, 2008; Ribeyre et al., 2014; Tokgöz and Eryiğit, 2015).

To support the prediction of multiple parents, node and edge transitions leave the stack unchanged, as in other work on transition-based dependency graph parsing (Sagae and Tsujii, 2008; Ribeyre et al., 2014; Tokgöz and Eryiğit, 2015).

To support the prediction of multiple parents, node and edge transitions leave the stack unchanged, as in other work on transition-based dependency graph parsing (Sagae and Tsujii, 2008; Ribeyre et al., 2014; Tokgöz and Eryiğit, 2015).
To handle discontinuous nodes, SWAP pops the second node on the stack and adds it to the top of the buffer, as with the similarly named transition in previous work (Nivre, 2009; Maier, 2015).
The choice of classifier and feature representation has been shown to play an important role in transition-based parsing (Chen and Manning, 2014; Andor et al., 2016; Kiperwasser and Goldberg, 2016).
uses an architecture similar to that of Chen and Manning (2014), but with two rectified linear layers instead of one layer with cube activation.

, 2015); UPARSE (Maier and Lichte, 2016), a transition-based constituency parser supporting discontinuous constituents; and two bilexical tree parsers: MaltParser (Nivre et al., 2007), and the stack LSTM-based parser of Dyer et al.

Linguistically expressive grammars such as HPSG (Pollard and Sag, 1994), CCG (Steedman, 2000) and TAG (Joshi and Schabes, 1997) provide a theory of the syntax-semantics interface, and have been used as a basis for semantic parsers by defining compositional semantics on top of them (Flickinger, 2000; Bos, 2005, among others).

Another line of work addresses parsing into AMRs (Flanigan et al., 2014; Vanderwende et al., 2015; Pust et al., 2015; Artzi et al., 2015), which, like UCCA, abstract away from syntactic distinctions and represent meaning directly, using OntoNotes predicates (Weischedel et al.

Another line of work addresses parsing into AMRs (Flanigan et al., 2014; Vanderwende et al., 2015; Pust et al., 2015; Artzi et al., 2015), which, like UCCA, abstract away from syntactic distinctions and represent meaning directly, using OntoNotes predicates (Weischedel et al.
Indeed, despite considerable technical effort (Flanigan et al., 2014; Pourdamghani et al., 2014; Werling et al., 2015), concept identification is only about 80%–90% accurate.

Several transition-based AMR parsers have been proposed: CAMR assumes syntactically parsed input, processing dependency trees into AMR (Wang et al., 2015a,b, 2016; Goodman et al., 2016). In contrast, the parsers of Damonte et al. (2017) and Zhou et al.

Several transition-based AMR parsers have been proposed: CAMR assumes syntactically parsed input, processing dependency trees into AMR (Wang et al., 2015a,b, 2016; Goodman et al., 2016). In contrast, the parsers of Damonte et al. (2017) and Zhou et al. (2016) do not require syntactic pre-processing.

Several transition-based AMR parsers have been proposed: CAMR assumes syntactically parsed input, processing dependency trees into AMR (Wang et al., 2015a,b, 2016; Goodman et al., 2016). In contrast, the parsers of Damonte et al. (2017) and Zhou et al. (2016) do not require syntactic pre-processing. Damonte et al. (2017) perform concept identification using a simple heuristic selecting the most frequent graph for each token, and Zhou et al.

Several transition-based AMR parsers have been proposed: CAMR assumes syntactically parsed input, processing dependency trees into AMR (Wang et al., 2015a,b, 2016; Goodman et al., 2016). In contrast, the parsers of Damonte et al. (2017) and Zhou et al. (2016) do not require syntactic pre-processing. Damonte et al. (2017) perform concept identification using a simple heuristic selecting the most frequent graph for each token, and Zhou et al. (2016) perform concept identification and parsing jointly.

We believe UCCA’s merits in providing a cross-linguistically applicable, broadcoverage annotation will support ongoing efforts to incorporate deeper semantic structures into various applications, such as sentence simplification (Narayan and Gardent, 2014) and summarization (Liu et al.

metadata.abstractText: We present the first parser for UCCA, a cross-linguistically applicable framework for semantic representation, which builds on extensive typological work and supports rapid annotation. UCCA poses a challenge for existing parsing techniques, as it exhibits reentrancy (resulting in DAG structures), discontinuous structures and non-terminal nodes corresponding to complex semantic units. To our knowledge, the conjunction of these formal properties is not supported by any existing parser. Our transition-based parser, which uses a novel transition set and features based on bidirectional LSTMs, has value not just for UCCA parsing: its ability to handle more general graph structures can inform the development of parsers for other semantic DAG structures, and in languages that frequently use discontinuous structures.
